data.title: Dayton Delight: Carillon Historical Park
data.meta_description: Tips for visiting Dayton Carillon Historical Park with kids. What to expect on your visit to the Carillon Park and Brewery.
data.text:
A visit to Carillon Historical Park in Dayton

So youâ€™ve been to Cincinnati to check out the Newport Aquarium or Kings Island. You went to Cleveland to visit the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and maybe cheer on the home team at Progressive Field. And of course, you have been to COSI in Columbus and wandered the streets of German Village. But Dayton? Whatâ€™s in Dayton? A quick internet search proved that I was going to need more than one day in Dayton, but for our first visit, we chose the Carillon Historical Park.

We packed some snacks and headed west via I-70 to the land of Orville and Wilbur Wright and the home of the Carillon Historical Park. The park, situated on 65 acres just outside the downtown area would provide much of the history of Daytonâ€™s rich industrial and innovative past.

Our first stop was the newly opened Carillon Brewing Company. The restaurant is a fully functioning 1850s-style brewery. The smell of hops overtakes you as you enter! We sat on the patio and enjoyed a few tastes of their traditional brews while dining on delicious cheeseburgers. We joked about taking our kids to a brewery, but Carillon Historical Park is a family-friendly destination and their brewery is no different.

So why take children that are 5 and under to a Historical Park?

Because it didnâ€™t FEEL like a museum but instead a hands-on historical display.

Climb aboard the front of an old steam train. Ride on the 1930s Ohio-built Carousel. Sit at a desk in an 1890s schoolroom. See some of the first Huffy bicycles, built-in Dayton!

The 1905 Wright Flyer III is on display. A National Historic Landmark, it was hard to consider that this was manâ€™s first flying machine (and Iâ€™m scared to think what it was like flying on a plane that had a max horsepower of 25)!

Tips for visiting the Carillon Historical Park with kids

The Historical Park charges $12/adult and $8 per child over 3. We used our AAA membership to get a $4 total discount. (They donâ€™t advertise this, but the sweet lady at the gift shop told us). Save those ones though, youâ€™ll need them to get tokens for the Carousel ride which is $1/person.

At 65-acres, the Park is large, but mostly handicap accessible. Bring your stroller and some good walking shoes. Youâ€™ll need both!

While there is a cafe inside the park (the Brewery is located just outside the park) you may want to bring a few water bottles. We were there on a HOT day, and unsure of the rules, we didnâ€™t take in a water bottle. Big mistake!

And itâ€™s not necessarily a tip, but make sure you press the button to hear the wax sculpture of Edith Deeds give her presentation on the Carillon! Itâ€™s unbelievably life-like and gives a great history of the Carillon. (It may, however, scare your 5 yr old). While on the grounds, enjoy that sweet music. ðŸ™‚

Check out the website for the Carillon Historical Park HERE.

Have you been to Dayton? Our list of places to visit on our next trip is still growing! What should we see next?
